description.narrative: UN Country Team Coordination and Joint Programming in implementation of Sustainable Development Goals, aligning UN programme cycle with national development cycle, UNDAF implementation, UN M&E framework
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Project defines activities of the UN Coordination Office in Montenegro aimed to support coordination of all resident and non-resident UN Organisations in financial, programmatic, operational and communication terms.

description.narrative: a) The UNCT and the Government engaged in discussions on key national priorities which will represent the outcomes of the Integrated UN Programme; b) The Integrated UN Programme 2012-2016 developed and adopted by the Joint Country Steering Committee, c) The joint resource mobilization strategy developed and implemented; d) The UN Eco Shared Premises project presented to UN WGCP and adopted; e) One UN feasibility study developed; f) At least one Negotiation Skill training for the UNCT facilitated and at least four planning retreats for UNCT held until 2013; g) At least one HACT workshop for UN staff and national counterparts facilitated; h) At least one individual hired for coordination support.

comment.narrative: a) Cooperation between the UNCT and the Government of Montenegro is at a satisfactory level but should be enhanced in order to prepare and implement Delivering as One (2007); b) The UN System and the Government have no joint programme of cooperation (2007); c) No joint resource mobilization strategy (2007); d) The UN System in Montenegro has no common premises (2007); e) No feasibility study on One UN developed (2007); f) No Negotiations Skills training for the UNCT held and no planning retreats held (2007); g) National counterparts are unaware of the HACT (2007); h) One temporary position in UN Coordination Office (2007).
The UNCT provided continuous, enhanced and coherent support to Montenegro in the overall reform process and implementation of the National Programme for Integration of Montenegro in the EU.

The UNCT Montenegro supported the overall EU accession process though its human rights and development programmes and activities agreed with the Government in the form of 2016 UN Annual Work Plan. The UN AWP is aligned with national priorities. The UNCT Montenegro and the Government adopted a new UNDAF 2017-2021 in March 2016. UNDAF is aligned with the 2030 Agenda on Sustainable Development and the Sustainable Development Goals. It is also particularly framed by the EU accession reform agenda systematically pursued by the Government of Montenegro.

1. Strengthening the Capacities of the Government of Montenegro for the EU Accession Negotiations on Chapter 23:
- Provide expert and technical support to the Ministry of Justice for the continuation of the implementation of the Action plan for the Chapter 23 and Strategy for the reform of judiciary (2014-2018) and Action plan for its implementation;
2. Strengthening the capacities of the Ministry of Justice of Montenegro in the area of international legal assistance in criminal matters:
- Provide support in implementation of training programmes in the area of international legal assistance in criminal matters.

Capacities of the Government of Montenegro for the EU Accession Negotiations on Chapter 23 strengthened through expert and technical support to the Ministry of Justice of Montenegro in the realization of the Action plan for the implementation of the National Strategy for the Reform of the Judiciary (2014-2018).

description.narrative: The project will adopt a comprehensive approach to minimizing the carbon footprint of tourism sector with the immediate target to maintain tourist sector related GHG emissions in Montenegro
capital of a political entity

1. The tourism sector related Green House Gas (GHG) emissions not exceeding the level in 2013 (Year: 2020) 2. Amount of reduced CO2 emissions by the investments facilitated by the project (Year 2019) 3. Extent to which financing mechanisms are being accessed to support low-carbon tourism (Year 2019) 4. Annually reported GHG emissions from tourism sector (2016 onward) 5. Number of amended Laws and Strategies introducing provisions on low-carbon tourism 6. Number of low-carbon spatial plans developed 7. Level of awareness on low carbon tourism in Montenegro

comment.narrative: 1. 77 ktCO2 (Year 2013) 2. 0 (2014) 3. Not adequately: There are no finance mechanisms to support low-carbon tourism 4. Not adequately: The system for greenhouse gas (GHG) emission monitoring in tourism sector does not exist. 5. 0: Low carbon tourism related provisions not included in the Laws and Strategies 6. 0: Low-carbon spatial plans not developed 7. Not adequately: Level of awareness on low-carbon tourism in Montenegro low

1. Prepare and implement the first Call for Proposals to co-finance pilot projects leading to reduction of CO2 in tourism sector in municipalities Herceg Novi, Tivat, Kotor and Cetinje 2. External validation of developed GHG Methodology for tourism sector 3. Inventory of GHG in tourism sector for 2014 and 2015 4. Eco-certification initiated in 20 hotels/apartmens 5. Web based carbon footprint calculator for tourists and hotels designed and established 6. Web page of the TCNT Project established 7. Pilot Carbon compensation scheme initiated and promoted

MRV protocols developed for 3 investment projects that will be implemented and supported by the end of 2016.
Bus station in Cetinje reconstructed as low carbon tourism welcome centre and the bike rack for electric bikes established in Tivat bus station. The first Call for Proposals has been implemented and so far three pilot projects have been selected for further support in the amount of 150,000 EUR. Low carbon development principles and measures incorporated in the framework Law on Tourism, Spatial Plan for Special Purpose Coastal Area, National Sustainable Development Strategy, The Study on Low Cost Carriers impact on tourism elaborated. The Polycentric Sustainable Urban Mobility Plan developed for four municipalities. • Various promo materials for the project were developed (flyers, pvc stickers, sun bags, climate change supporting postcards, roll-ups, envelopes, folders, donation boxes for tourist ready to donate for sustainable projects in Montenegro, etc.) and distributed on visible and attractive locations throughout Montenegro Many public events in Montenegro were held under the slogans of our project and/or broadcasting our video on the video wall displays (New Year’s Eve celebrations on the coast, sport events, bicycle events, etc.) Online Carbon calculator available at www.calculateco2.me for tourists is developed and integrated in more than 30 tourism websites in Montenegro (hotels, tour operators, visitor centers etc.) Project web page developed and available at www.lowcarbonmne.me

Complete the GHG Inventory for Tourism sector for 2014 and 2015 Implement of the 2nd Call for Proposals Prepare the program for establishment of Eco Fund Eco certification of 10 tourist facilities Intensify partnership with hotel industry, music festivals,

1. GHG Inventory for tourism sector for 2016 completed, data presented to the MSDT 2. II Call for Proposals successfully implemented in partnership with the Chamber of Economy - SLOA - 751.569 EUR allocated for co-financing of 22 projects 3.Program for Establishment of Eco fund prepared, adopted by the Steering Committee for establishment of Eco Fund, Decision on establishing Eco Fund ready for further procedure in the Government 4. 10 hotels received eco-certificate in 2017 with project support, 20 energy audits were conducted 5. The Project has partnered with four music festivals and piloted three new carbon-offset models and greening music festivals 6.The Project was presented at the International Tourism Fare in Belgrade and WTM in London 7. The 2nd Survey on Low Carbon Tourism Products and Services is in final phase and will show progress compared to findings in 2015 8. The CO received the SDG Story Award in the category 1 – The Greatest influencer, for the Photo essay: Montenegro makes carbon neutral tourism possible produced by the Project

comment.narrative: to establish an internal interoperability framework between all the connected institutions of the Montenegrin social welfare system, and ensure specific inter-institutional links between connected institutions of the system covered by Phase II. A central component of the Project is the development and implementation of new ISWIS components related to social welfare institutions, as well as supporting interconnection modules, which will result in fully established and functional Montenegrin social welfare information system. training of civil servants in the MLSW in the field of management and best practices when it comes to similar systems, and a comprehensive training for the staff of social and welfare institutions on how to use the ISWIS and its potentials.

1. implementation of Amendments on Law on Social Protection and of the new law on Constitutional Court Decision (benefit for mothers with 3+ children) through ISWIS including issuing of over different packages of 62.000 individual decisions for end beneficiaries through new functionalities of ISWIS. Savings on social public expenditure estimated at over 60 mil euro annually. 2. contracting and management of long-term contract (31/12/21) with applicative software developer 3. fully operational and regularly maintained ICT infrastructure for the Social welfare sector – contracting 4. continuous learning for human capacities building – visits, workshops organized, manuals, etc.. 5. produced standard/unified Annual Report for Social Welfare Centers for social transfers and numerous ad hoc reports – all demographic variables disaggregated.

1. Amendments and new law implemented timely and all the benefits processed to poor and vulnerable with no delay. Focus was also on close M&E and intensive support to staff to perfrom timely 2. Long-term contracting (31/12/21) with applicative software developer 3. Long-term contracting (31/12/21) maintenance of servers, hardware (32 locations) and networks for all social welfare sector 4. Continuous learning for human capacities building – visits (6), workshops (5) organized, meetings, manuals updated, new templates, etc..

title.narrative: Improving the efficiency of justice through ICT

description.narrative: Improved efficiency of justice through the use of the Judicial Information System, enabling the concept of a “paperless court” and use of reliable judicial statistics

title.narrative: CSA Improving the efficiency of justice through ICT

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of men with access to legal aid services
Number of women with access to legal aid services
Total number of people with access to legal aid services
Improving the efficiency of justice through the use of ICT in the day-to-day work and management of the judicial institutions.
capital of a political entity
Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative:
1. Judicial statistics, including standards for measuring productivity of judges, average time spent on cases and workload of judges, etc. not developed. Gender-disaggregated data non-existent.
2. Accountability of judges and prosecutors defined by the normative framework and relevant strategic documents, which need to be improved and implementation of the established criteria in practice needs to be enhanced.
3. Records’ keeping in the Montenegrin courts is performed manually, which affects the efficiency of the judiciary to a considerable extent. The major strategic documents define a clear need for increasing the efficiency by means of introducing the concept of a paperless court.
4. Judicial Information System established, but it needs to be upgraded and made operational for all the judicial institutions, in line with the recommendations by the relevant strategic documents.

1. Conditions for the improvement of management in judiciary, developing "paperless court" concept and PRIS reform established - ICT Strategy for Justice System of Montenegro (2016-2020) and Action plan for the implementation of the Strategy produced and adopted by the Government; 2. PRIS upgrade enabled through the creation of the revised project document for the project MNE-14/0023 “Improving efficiency of justice through the use of ICT”.

- Provide support to the Ministry of Justice of Montenegro and other relevant judicial authorities in the realization of the recently adopted ICT Strategy for judiciary 2016-2020 and Action plan for its implementation.

- Support provided to the Ministry of Justice of Montenegro and other relevant judicial authorities in the realization of the recently adopted ICT Strategy for judiciary 2016-2020 and Action plan for its implementation.

title.narrative: Comprehensive Environmentally Sound Management of PCBs

description.narrative: Environmentally sound management of PCB waste and equipment containing PCB in accordance with the requirement of ratified Stockholm convention.

title.narrative: RFP 02-18 Sampling and analysis of insulating oil from 510 pole mounted transformers

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level
Number of additional males benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Number of additional females benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Total number of additional people benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Environmentally sound management of PCB waste and equipment containing PCB in accordance with the requirement of ratified Stockholm convention.
capital of a political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

National environmentally sound management (ESM) system of PCB chemicals and waste drafted, and implemented by 2020
700 tons of pure PCBs and 200 tons of low-concentrated PCBs/related waste are safely managed and disposed of/decontaminated by the end of the project, thus reducing global and local environment from exposure to these hazardous wastes

comment.narrative:
People and workers are currently exposed to the risk posed by PCB containing equipment stored or online. Financial resources were used to buy disposal service abroad without creating job opportunities in the country. Current PCB management regulation has some deficiencies and requires appropriate capacity and cooperation from PCB equipment/waste owners to be enforced No national PCB management plan prepared and comprehensively implemented as of now.
No comprehensive ESM system is in place to address the national PCB situation, and power equipment is exposed to continuous cross-contamination A systematic PCB inventory, including PCB identification and labelling is missing.

1. Organize Inception workshop 2. Form Project Team 3. Collect data about the equipment (potentially contaminated) from all partners 4. Start with development of PCB inventory 5. Organize training on identification of PCB 6. Develop documentation necessary for the upgrade/construction of at least one storage facility 7. Do the review of current legal acts that regulate management of PCBs and suggest the improvements

1. Inception workshop was organized on 26th May 2017. 2. Project team was formed 3. All available data was collected from the partners, and in addition to this, new partners were identified and included in this project. 4. Center for Eco-Toxicological Research - CETI was contracted to do the sampling and analysis of the equipment and waste suspected to be PCB contaminated. CETI started with the activities. 5. Training on PCB identification and usage of fast screening tests was organized in October 2017, with 38 participants from private sector and Governmental institutions. 6. It was very difficult to identify future storage facilities, we managed to do that in December, therefore documentation for construction works is not finalized. 7. Suggestions for the improvements of 3 legal acts was submitted to the Ministry for Sustainable Development and Tourism

description.narrative: This project aims to enable Montenegro to prepare, produce and disseminate its Third National Communication to the Conference of the Parties of the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change according to Decision 17/CP8 and other guidance provided.

comment.narrative: - Two NCs prepared, an Initial NC in 2011, the Second NC (SNC) in 2015. - Montenegro submitted its First Biennial Update Report (FBUR) in January 2016.

SWIS is ISO certified in course of 2018.

ISWIS is not ISO certified
